habitat_description:
Corvus caurinus forages primarily along intertidal zones, including beaches, rock outcrops, and mudflats (James and Verbeek, 1983; Saunders and Ydenberg, 1995; Verbeek and Butler, 1999; Robinette and Ha, 2000; Robinette and Ha, 2002; O’Brien et al., 2005) and is known to cache food in forests near such areas (Saunders and Ydenberg, 1995). The species nests in a broad range of habitats, including: forests (Campbell et al., 1997; Robinette and Crockett, 1999; Robinette and Ha, 2002); shrub-covered, maritime headlands (Campbell et al., 1997); meadows (Verbeek, 1998); hedgerows (Moul and Elliott, 1994); estuaries (Campbell et al., 1997); residential areas (Robinette and Crockett, 1999; Verbeek and Butler, 1999; Robinette and Ha, 2002); and at landfills (Verbeek and Butler, 1999). Northwestern crows have also been documented on cropland (Peterson et al., 2001).

The maximum elevation for the species is around 1700 m (Campbell et al., 1997).

C. caurinus is rarely found more than a few kilometers from tidewater (Campbell et al., 1997) and specifically avoids forest interior (Verbeek and Butler, 1999).
